comment info:

Storage capacity limits are skyrocketing because of more and more shopping online and the demand for products has increased over the past couple of years. Among human delays, wildfires and other natural disasters extend the time of transit for a product to reach its destination.

I noticed that the graph is showing the process of items being transported from Indonesia to Orlando, Florida typically,  compared to currently. I noticed that the amount of time that it currently takes is much longer than the amount of time that it typically takes. In particular, the lead times was increased by 10 days because of capacity limits & anchorage time was increased by 15 days because of port congestions. 

I wonder why there are such major delays when transporting these goods & I wonder what is causing the port congestions. Is it caused by the pandemic? Do these longer Cargo Transit Times also increase the demand for items in Orlando, Florida?

This might relate to my community and I because the demand for certain supplies may increase because of the delays. This may change prices of items and cause inflation in the economy (long term.)

"28 More Days, How Much More $?"

name: Panagiotis Papanikolaou
comment info:
It is a widely held belief that bottlenecks disrupt global trade and affect us all. 
To begin with, lots of delays are undoubtedly observed during cargo transit times and cause supply chain problems, which are really crucial. These delays may be results of misorganization, extra anchorage time or even wildfires. It goes without saying that these retardations may be proven extremely important and can impact negatively on our lives, relationships, habits, or even priorities.
In my opinion, should global trade be disrupted, we will all be deprived of food, medication and clothes, due to the undenible fact that our world operates through trade, imports and exports, as globalization is increased day by day.
I am inclined to think that global trade is an integral part of our lives and existence, as the fact of realizing that we, people, cannot do without it is really vital.
